description: From Spanish saco (“a sack, a half-carga”), from Old Spanish saco, from Latin saccus, from Ancient Greek σάκκος (sákkos, “sack, sackcloth”), from Semitic. Doublet of sac, saccus, sack, and sakkos.

entries.meaning: (historical) A traditional Spanish unit of dry measure, equivalent to about 111 L.
